{"blocks":[{"key":"cuc14","text":"We have 2 source plates, only with 96 samples and the other with 50.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tegi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8t2gq","text":"With the first source plate we want to create 1 plate with only samples from the source plate. With the second source we want to create 2 final plates, 1 with Ampicilin and another with Kanamycin inoculated with these samples starting to transfer samples from the 3rd column of the source plate. As well, we want to create 1 replica of those 2 plates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":351}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fo0n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9m5o","text":"Finally, we want to create 1 additional plate without only Ampicilin in 73 wells starting from the well C2","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":106}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3o3sj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cabr","text":"We need to change the tip during the sample transferring to be every time the pipette aspirates from the source plate but we just need the tip during the distribution of the media to change everytime it changes of reagent.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":222}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dgb3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"232ih","text":"We will use a computer with a Windows 10 system.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fn7r1","text":"Start Run","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c77uo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d08ib","text":"The procedure that the robot is going to do is mainly divided in 3 parts:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9viob","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hn7k","text":"Creation of primer sets combining water, primer(s) and polymerase","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"184bf","text":"Mixing and distributing the primer set(s)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpqtl","text":"Transferring samples to the corresponding wells of all set of primers","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhoml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6vodf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9o1o7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":18,"offset":190,"style":"italic"}],"key":"d5ulq","text":"One or more final plates (usually PCR plates) with the mix for each set of primers combined with the colony samples and an excel file containig th emapping of each final plate in the folder /data/user_storage of the robot","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"des8c","text":"Fill the template with the corresponding values (PCR conditions, number of primer pairs, output map, availability of OT-2 thermocycler  etc...) and save file as VariablesPCR.xlsx (if the file has another name the LAP format script will not read the file).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":161,"length":17},{"style":"bold","offset":161,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6crdg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dl5v3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5528m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1us59","text":"Verify volume range of the OT-2 pipettes available with the volume of a single reaction.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"479cl","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7he40","text":"This can be a source of the errors displayed by the app in later steps","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"76gmu","text":"Wipe the surface of the deck with 70% ethanol to clean and desinfect the surfaces","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":81}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2nmql","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3mik2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cq9sd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":69,"offset":72}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eablf","text":"For more information in how to clean the robot go to the following link https://support.opentrons.com/s/article/Cleaning-the-robot-s-surfaces","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"0406AC793E6511EDB7F00A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://support.opentrons.com/s/article/Cleaning-the-robot-s-surfaces"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3c451","text":"Set the respective labwares in the slots as the OT App and the instruction file set","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etl7h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82t4l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3b54j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hfgf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jpb0","text":"Make sure that the source and final A1 wells are at the left top (common mistake), and each labware fits appropierly.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"crn80","text":"Set the different reactives in their respective coldblock positions, as stated in the instruction file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ohlp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9aem4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ou1a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9a7mv","text":"Make sure that the caps of these 1.5mL eppendorfors are removed (cut them) so they are not hanging and the pipette(s) do not have the possibility to crash with them","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"db4bi","text":"Make sure the needed calibrations are done","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":21,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bqsvq","text":"Select Robot to Perform Script","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8unjm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"368j1","text":"Click in the protocol -\u003e Start setup -\u003e Choose the OT where the file VariablesPlateIncubation.xlsx is -\u003e Proceed To Setup","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":68},{"style":"bold","offset":69,"length":29},{"style":"bold","offset":99,"length":22},{"style":"italic","offset":69,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aiuic","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"rd87","text":"After clicking on Proceed to Setup, you should obtain the labware positions in the Labware tab and the reagents, with their corresponding volume, in the Liquids tab.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":82,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":152,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3t983","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"83ot7","text":"In case the protocol with the set variables cannot run, an error will occur during the run. Many errors are contemplated already and have a specific message that hints the user what could have gone wrong.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3178r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9inop","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2roj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvtv6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"72l8v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":125,"style":"bold"},{"length":74,"offset":130,"style":"bold"}],"key":"a0ekq","text":"The volume of the initial samples is established to be 90% of the max volume of the well, but this is only a recommendation. Just make sure that there is enough volume to transfer to all the final plates.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8r7ql","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":60,"offset":84,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3fgll","text":"On the other hand, the volume of the reagents is precisely what is needed, so it is suggested always to add more to consider the pipetting error.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":60,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"cipn2","text":"It is recommended that you perform a labware position check.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4lglv","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cv543","text":"You can do it with test plates after loading the script but before cleaning the surface. That way, you reduce the probability of contamination (using test plates and labware) and pipetting errors (position check).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"5t8sf","text":"Run Protocol in OT","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9v4gv","text":"We want to perform a PCR mix preparation of 93 colonies and 2 controls that are in 2 source plates (40 colonies + 2 control samples in 1 plate and 54 colonies starting from the A4 well in the other plate but we dont want to take the sample in the well D6) with 2 primer sets. The first plate will have a map of identities(names) but the second one wont.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":353}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bmfo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bat0n","text":"We are going to have a heater-shaker module available but not a thermocycler. We are going to set the shaker to a high RPMs so we want the maximum volume on the mixing tubes, the tube sthat will contain the PCR mix with primers, polymerase mix and water, to be 1mL\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":264}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53ame","text":"We will use a computer with a Windows 10 system","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7p51a","text":"Sequencing reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8963h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"787qp","text":"Place all read files under a single directory. These files can be in either FASTA or FASTQ format, but formats cannot be mixed (i.e. the tool will not process both FASTA and FASTQ files simultaneously).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":69,"length":6},{"style":"italic","offset":82,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct6v7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d1tc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fjaej","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65dl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ef5ni","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgdqk","text":"Each FASTA or FASTQ file can contain multiple reads, and multiple files can be provided. All reads within all FASTA or FASTQ file in the directory will be processed. It is therefore important that each read has a unique ID (the ID of the sequence follows the first \u003e character in the FASTA format, and the first @ character in FASTQ format).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":116,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4kgu5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgplo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tgh6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"13b2p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2uil1","text":"The file extension is largely irrelevant and can be specified later using the --input-ext option. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bjaej","text":"If quality control and read trimming is desired, the FASTQ format is required. Sanger, Solexa/Illumina1.0 and Ilumina\u003e1.3 quality score encodings are supported for FASTQ files.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8t4d8","text":"Later, when attaching (optional) metadata to the results, the ID will also be used to identify the plate and well from which the read was sampled. It is recommended that IDs are generated in a systematic way which facilitates this identification.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"528vo","text":"Sample plate metadata","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4btqr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a4t7n","text":"Additional metadata can be attached to individual sequencing reads by providing the metadata in a grid, where position in the grid can be mapped onto samples in a well plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9sseg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7pmof","text":"The grid, or grids, can be provided in excel format (XLSX). The first row of the excel file should contain numbers that index the columns of the plate, and the first column should contain letters that index the rows of the plate. Each cell corresponding to a well in a plate should contain the metadata that you wish to attach to the sequencing reads originating from that well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3931h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1flma","text":"The name of the files themselves should follow the format: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aaqoa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ct32","text":"\u003cPLATE_IDENTIFIER\u003e_\u003cMETADATA_LABEL\u003e.xlsx","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kfj1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1e6il","text":"where metadata that will appear in the output table.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"n1ae","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9sj2d","text":"\u003cPLATE_IDENTIFIER\u003e {"blocks":[{"key":"9noer","text":"Install FastQC","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cqrt3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9d1kq","text":"FastQC is a tool used for quality control of high-throughput sequence data. {"blocks":[{"key":"6nqcg","text":"Quality control report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlns5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e67kl","text":"Optionally, tnfind can generate a fastqc quality control report for your sequencing reads, that contains information that will be useful if you intend to later trim your reads based on quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1m0ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gogg","text":"Passing the option -qc when running tnfind will generate the quality control report. The report will be saved in the output_dir in the file records_fastqc.html, you can open this file with your favourite web browser.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecjrk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3tnou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78vkk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1ftd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running fastqc as part of tnfind","description":"","guid":"AF101C31349311F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -qc","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"calo","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command fastqc on your computer system. {"blocks":[{"key":"82d0h","text":"Download the example sequencing read files, transposon sequences file and reference genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"el70r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7lm8m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lp9e","text":"You can download the example data from https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk and unzip into a directory called data, or use the command:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":39,"length":38}],"data":{}},{"key":"7as6h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3cvd5","text":"To create a directory called data, under the tnfind-example directory, containing the example data files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88d0o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"affiliation":null,"can_edit":true,"guid":"2833B21B34AF11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","link":"https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk","name":"tnfind example data"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3E2A721D34AD11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk"}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Download the example data and unzip","description":"","guid":"6AA2A47A34AD11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"wget https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk/download -O data.zip \u0026\u0026 unzip data.zip \u0026\u0026 rm data.zip","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3fqlh","text":"Default outputs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"begpg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak68k","text":"results.xlsx is an excel spreadsheet containing the summary of the tnfind results.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dll","text":"tnfind also produces one GENBANK file per input read, which is annotated with the supposed transposon sequence and genome alignments for the read. The genome alignments are also annotated with corresponding genome features and loci, if those are available in the reference genome files.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6dvv9","text":"Transposon sequences","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fp8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23iap","text":"Sequences belonging to the transposon systems used should be provided in either GENBANK, FASTA, or FASTQ format. {"blocks":[{"key":"9l0nh","text":"Quality-based trimming","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ar1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ihvo","text":"To ensure that sequencing quality does not affect your results, you may wish to trim your input sequences where quality is low. tnfind can do this using the sickle tool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82hc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f20le","text":"Passing the option -trim when running tnfind will trim your reads before processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd7ui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"72vnk","text":"Optionally, the --trim-length and --trim-quality options can passed to tnfind to control the severity of the trimming.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbepu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8a108","text":"If --trim-length is not given explicitly, its default value is 20. If --trim-quality is not given explicitly, its default value is also 20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dubj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38cg4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e70p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a4cue","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qmtt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle to trim reads ","description":"","guid":"AA7960F7349411F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle and with custom trim length and quality","description":"","guid":"6951A560349511F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim --trim-length 30 --trim-quality 25","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7beij","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command sickle on your computer system. If you have installed sickle somewhere that is not on your PATH, you may also provide the path/to/sickle to the -trim argument.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ahil2","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b1tkf","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"gkvt","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle in a custom location","description":"","guid":"2479A5D6349611F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim /path/to/your/sickle","os_name":"","os_version":""},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"command"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5t0ts","text":"SAM output","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17suh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vrhu","text":"Part of tnfind's processing is a multiple sequence alignment between your sequencing reads and the reference genome(s). Optionally, this multiple sequence alignment may be saved in SAM format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe5sl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f68v3","text":"Passing the option -sam to tnfind will save a multiple sequence alignment in SAM format in the output_dir in the file samgenomes.sam.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk9po","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2idsq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with SAM output","description":"","guid":"F97F9F44349611F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -sam","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"20vvd","text":"Other input formats, types and file extensions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86d4r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq0nr","text":"The following options in combination in order to process input files with different formats, types and file extensions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79bdc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h34n","text":"--input-type: is the format of the read files and should be either fasta or fastq. The default is fastq.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15m5u","text":"--input-ext: is the file extension of the read files. This can be anything. The default is ab1 if the --input-type is fastq or fasta if the --input-type is fasta.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6rfd","text":"--sequencing-type: the type of sequencing used to obtain the reads. This can be either sanger, solexa or illumina. The default is sanger.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1c0h","text":"--transposon-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the transposon sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c86fd","text":"--genome-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the genome sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m84q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evh16","text":"For example, if you have FASTQ format reads that have file extension fatstq instead of ab1, you could run:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ef07g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4r5ig","text":"Or if you do not have an annotated reference genome, and want to instead use a sequence-only FASTA file:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6f2jm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8m57e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Run tnfind on fastq files","description":"","guid":"16B24324349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb --input-ext fastq","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with FASTA reference genome","description":"","guid":"572B021F349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.fasta --genome-type fasta","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2o18m","text":"results.xlsx","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79h3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhel2","text":"This is an excel spreadsheet which contains at least one row for every read in the input to tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2330v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56cqd","text":"If a particular read has multiple rows, then it was not possible to uniquely identify a position in the reference genome(s) for the transposon integration event. For example, because the integration has occurred within a genomic region which is repeated across the genome(s) (rRNAs for example, or genes with multiple copies, or genes that are shared among genomes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tlff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bstp5","text":"The columns of the excel describe various different statistics and information about the alignment. There are several groups.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34i0r","text":"Information about the sequencing read","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"148o5","text":"The first column is simply an indexing column and can be ignored.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtdj7","text":"The name column is the ID of the read obtained from the input file.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ad95","text":"The read length column is the length of the read (after trimming, if applicable).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6digf","text":"The multiple candidates column is true if the read has multiple rows and false otherwise. It can be used to filter uniquely identifiable integration events.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80vl6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d75d2","text":"Information about the transposon sequence found","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":47}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9im3s","text":"The transposon column contains the name of the supposed transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8at6f","text":"The transposon evalue column contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe7hf","text":"The transposon bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65tcd","text":"The transposon identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3f5dk","text":"The transposon length column indicates the length of the aligned part of the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j1t1","text":"The transposon start column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence begins.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfssg","text":"The transposon end column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence ends.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vr1e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nmur","text":"These columns are empty if no transposon sequence is found in the read.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33s2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cl28","text":"Information about the position in the genome","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6krss","text":"The genome offset column indicates the distance in base pairs between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j7dr","text":"The gap sequence is the read sequence (if any), between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41e9d","text":"The insertion locus is the name of the locus (if any) in the genome where the integration event is supposed to have occurred. This name comes from the annotated reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21bg2","text":"The insertion gene is the name of the gene into which the transposon sequence was integrated. This name comes from the annotated reference genome. If there is no such annotation this column shows \"None\"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l4ed","text":"The sequence type is the annotated type of the locus into which the integration has occurred. Again, this is taken from annotations on the reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26mub","text":"The insertion strand is the strand orientation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fit33","text":"The insertion product is the product annotation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8glg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a29f","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome, or if genome annotations are missing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsu8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ic5i","text":"Information about the genome alignment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rjd5","text":"The genome column contains the ID of the reference genome to which the read has been aligned.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dtv9","text":"The genome alignment evalue columns contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c29f","text":"The genome alignment bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ksj9","text":"The genome alignment identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbvk5","text":"The genome alignment length column contains the length in base pairs of the part of the read that was aligned to the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdd7v","text":"The genome alignment mismatch column contains the number of mismatches, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9fhr","text":"The genome alignment gaps column contains the number of gaps, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94srd","text":"The genome start column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9b6p","text":"The genome end column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63am1","text":"The genome strand column indicates the strand orientation on the genome of the alignment between the read and genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rk7u","text":"The genome loci column is a list of all the genomic loci contained within the genome alignment (as opposed to the single locus at the integration position reported in the insertion locus column).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":170,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o7qh","text":"The genome prefix column displays the sequence corresponding to the first 9 base pairs of genomic DNA contained in the read (the start of the read sequence that aligns with the genome). The size of the sequence displayed can be changed with the --genome-prefix option.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aud0p","text":"The genome alignment column shows the quality of the alignment of the genome prefix sequence with the genome. Exact matches are indicated with \"|\". Mismatches are indicated with \".\". Gaps are show as \"-\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16},{"style":"bold","offset":70,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eefr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f728h","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8pipg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c53nm","text":"Annotated reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq2q6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"132rh","text":"tnfind produces an annotated GENBANK file (file names ending in .processed.gb) for each input read that can be used to visually inspect the positions and alignments found to the both the transposon sequences and the genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62v1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45sgl","text":"These files can be opened using your favourite sequence viewer to see the arrangement of transposon and genomic sequences that tnfind thinks is most probable for each read. Genomic sequences are also annotated with features from their respective reference genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as1pv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64k8v","text":"An example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37g69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pddp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rkp9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d35i7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"31D5173C404F11F090B80A58A9FEAC02","height":191,"id":584661,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8s9go\",\"text\":\"An example of the GENBANK output from tnfind. In this case, the read 22CCRRAA000_C05 is annotated with a transposon sequence alignment, plus the IR (Inverted repeat) feature. There is a small gap between the end of the transposon sequence and the genomic sequence, which comes from the genome AE015451.2 and contains the gene hmgA. In this case, the read aligned with the plus strand of AE015451.2, but the hmgA gene is coded for on the minus strand.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"labelled_gb_output.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tq95cpi5f.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t48xcpi5f.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t48wcpi5f.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"20vvd","text":"Other input formats, types and file extensions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86d4r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq0nr","text":"The following options in combination in order to process input files with different formats, types and file extensions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79bdc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h34n","text":"--input-type: is the format of the read files and should be either fasta or fastq. The default is fastq.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15m5u","text":"--input-ext: is the file extension of the read files. This can be anything. The default is ab1 if the --input-type is fastq or fasta if the --input-type is fasta.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6rfd","text":"--sequencing-type: the type of sequencing used to obtain the reads. This can be either sanger, solexa or illumina. The default is sanger.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1c0h","text":"--transposon-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the transposon sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c86fd","text":"--genome-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the genome sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m84q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evh16","text":"For example, if you have FASTQ format reads that have file extension fatstq instead of ab1, you could run:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ef07g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4r5ig","text":"Or if you do not have an annotated reference genome, and want to instead use a sequence-only FASTA file:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6f2jm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8m57e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Run tnfind on fastq files","description":"","guid":"16B24324349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb --input-ext fastq","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with FASTA reference genome","description":"","guid":"572B021F349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.fasta --genome-type fasta","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6nqcg","text":"Quality control report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlns5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e67kl","text":"Optionally, tnfind can generate a fastqc quality control report for your sequencing reads, that contains information that will be useful if you intend to later trim your reads based on quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1m0ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gogg","text":"Passing the option -qc when running tnfind will generate the quality control report. The report will be saved in the output_dir in the file records_fastqc.html, you can open this file with your favourite web browser.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecjrk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3tnou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78vkk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1ftd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running fastqc as part of tnfind","description":"","guid":"AF101C31349311F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -qc","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"calo","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command fastqc on your computer system. If you have installed fastqc somewhere that is not on your PATH, you may also provide the path/to/fastqc to the -qc argument.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"68us3","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"63iv7","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vhd8","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with a custom location for fastqc","description":"","guid":"E0636618349311F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -qc /path/to/fastqc","os_name":"","os_version":""},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"command"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9l0nh","text":"Quality-based trimming","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ar1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ihvo","text":"To ensure that sequencing quality does not affect your results, you may wish to trim your input sequences where quality is low. tnfind can do this using the sickle tool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82hc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f20le","text":"Passing the option -trim when running tnfind will trim your reads before processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd7ui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"72vnk","text":"Optionally, the --trim-length and --trim-quality options can passed to tnfind to control the severity of the trimming.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbepu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8a108","text":"If --trim-length is not given explicitly, its default value is 20. If --trim-quality is not given explicitly, its default value is also 20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dubj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38cg4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e70p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a4cue","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qmtt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle to trim reads ","description":"","guid":"AA7960F7349411F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle and with custom trim length and quality","description":"","guid":"6951A560349511F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim --trim-length 30 --trim-quality 25","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7beij","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command sickle on your computer system. If you have installed sickle somewhere that is not on your PATH, you may also provide the path/to/sickle to the -trim argument.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ahil2","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b1tkf","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"gkvt","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle in a custom location","description":"","guid":"2479A5D6349611F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim /path/to/your/sickle","os_name":"","os_version":""},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"command"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5t0ts","text":"SAM output","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17suh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vrhu","text":"Part of tnfind's processing is a multiple sequence alignment between your sequencing reads and the reference genome(s). Optionally, this multiple sequence alignment may be saved in SAM format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe5sl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f68v3","text":"Passing the option -sam to tnfind will save a multiple sequence alignment in SAM format in the output_dir in the file samgenomes.sam.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk9po","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2idsq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with SAM output","description":"","guid":"F97F9F44349611F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -sam","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"avobh","text":"Obtaining help","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a95bt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aot5a","text":"There are many more optional arguments that control the behaviour of tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6j1fa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82urf","text":"They can be listed, alongside a short description of each, by running:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8h7i5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e5rap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Display the tnfind help","description":"","guid":"F086A60F349B11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind --help","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3fqlh","text":"Default outputs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"begpg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak68k","text":"results.xlsx is an excel spreadsheet containing the summary of the tnfind results.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dll","text":"tnfind also produces one GENBANK file per input read, which is annotated with the supposed transposon sequence and genome alignments for the read. The genome alignments are also annotated with corresponding genome features and loci, if those are available in the reference genome files.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2o18m","text":"results.xlsx","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79h3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhel2","text":"This is an excel spreadsheet which contains at least one row for every read in the input to tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2330v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56cqd","text":"If a particular read has multiple rows, then it was not possible to uniquely identify a position in the reference genome(s) for the transposon integration event. For example, because the integration has occurred within a genomic region which is repeated across the genome(s) (rRNAs for example, or genes with multiple copies, or genes that are shared among genomes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tlff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bstp5","text":"The columns of the excel describe various different statistics and information about the alignment. There are several groups.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34i0r","text":"Information about the sequencing read","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"148o5","text":"The first column is simply an indexing column and can be ignored.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtdj7","text":"The name column is the ID of the read obtained from the input file.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ad95","text":"The read length column is the length of the read (after trimming, if applicable).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6digf","text":"The multiple candidates column is true if the read has multiple rows and false otherwise. It can be used to filter uniquely identifiable integration events.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80vl6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d75d2","text":"Information about the transposon sequence found","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":47}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9im3s","text":"The transposon column contains the name of the supposed transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8at6f","text":"The transposon evalue column contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe7hf","text":"The transposon bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65tcd","text":"The transposon identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3f5dk","text":"The transposon length column indicates the length of the aligned part of the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j1t1","text":"The transposon start column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence begins.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfssg","text":"The transposon end column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence ends.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vr1e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nmur","text":"These columns are empty if no transposon sequence is found in the read.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33s2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cl28","text":"Information about the position in the genome","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6krss","text":"The genome offset column indicates the distance in base pairs between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j7dr","text":"The gap sequence is the read sequence (if any), between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41e9d","text":"The insertion locus is the name of the locus (if any) in the genome where the integration event is supposed to have occurred. This name comes from the annotated reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21bg2","text":"The insertion gene is the name of the gene into which the transposon sequence was integrated. This name comes from the annotated reference genome. If there is no such annotation this column shows \"None\"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l4ed","text":"The sequence type is the annotated type of the locus into which the integration has occurred. Again, this is taken from annotations on the reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26mub","text":"The insertion strand is the strand orientation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fit33","text":"The insertion product is the product annotation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8glg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a29f","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome, or if genome annotations are missing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsu8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ic5i","text":"Information about the genome alignment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rjd5","text":"The genome column contains the ID of the reference genome to which the read has been aligned.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dtv9","text":"The genome alignment evalue columns contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c29f","text":"The genome alignment bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ksj9","text":"The genome alignment identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbvk5","text":"The genome alignment length column contains the length in base pairs of the part of the read that was aligned to the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdd7v","text":"The genome alignment mismatch column contains the number of mismatches, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9fhr","text":"The genome alignment gaps column contains the number of gaps, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94srd","text":"The genome start column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9b6p","text":"The genome end column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63am1","text":"The genome strand column indicates the strand orientation on the genome of the alignment between the read and genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rk7u","text":"The genome loci column is a list of all the genomic loci contained within the genome alignment (as opposed to the single locus at the integration position reported in the insertion locus column).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":170,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o7qh","text":"The genome prefix column displays the sequence corresponding to the first 9 base pairs of genomic DNA contained in the read (the start of the read sequence that aligns with the genome). The size of the sequence displayed can be changed with the --genome-prefix option.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aud0p","text":"The genome alignment column shows the quality of the alignment of the genome prefix sequence with the genome. Exact matches are indicated with \"|\". Mismatches are indicated with \".\". Gaps are show as \"-\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16},{"style":"bold","offset":70,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eefr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f728h","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8pipg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c53nm","text":"Annotated reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq2q6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"132rh","text":"tnfind produces an annotated GENBANK file (file names ending in .processed.gb) for each input read that can be used to visually inspect the positions and alignments found to the both the transposon sequences and the genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62v1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45sgl","text":"These files can be opened using your favourite sequence viewer to see the arrangement of transposon and genomic sequences that tnfind thinks is most probable for each read. Genomic sequences are also annotated with features from their respective reference genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as1pv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64k8v","text":"An example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37g69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pddp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rkp9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d35i7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"326AADE9404F11F090B80A58A9FEAC02","height":191,"id":584663,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8s9go\",\"text\":\"An example of the GENBANK output from tnfind. In this case, the read 22CCRRAA000_C05 is annotated with a transposon sequence alignment, plus the IR (Inverted repeat) feature. There is a small gap between the end of the transposon sequence and the genomic sequence, which comes from the genome AE015451.2 and contains the gene hmgA. In this case, the read aligned with the plus strand of AE015451.2, but the hmgA gene is coded for on the minus strand.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"labelled_gb_output.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tq95cpi5f.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t48zcpi5f.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/traxcpi5f.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t48ycpi5f.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b482g","text":"Open the docker terminal ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8isfh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j5h4","text":"The lewisgrozinger/tnatlas docker image contains all the software you need in order to run tnfind.
