{"blocks":[{"key":"20vvd","text":"Other input formats, types and file extensions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86d4r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq0nr","text":"The following options in combination in order to process input files with different formats, types and file extensions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79bdc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h34n","text":"--input-type: is the format of the read files and should be either fasta or fastq. The default is fastq.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15m5u","text":"--input-ext: is the file extension of the read files. This can be anything. The default is ab1 if the --input-type is fastq or fasta if the --input-type is fasta.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6rfd","text":"--sequencing-type: the type of sequencing used to obtain the reads. This can be either sanger, solexa or illumina. The default is sanger.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1c0h","text":"--transposon-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the transposon sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c86fd","text":"--genome-type: is the format of the file(s) containing the genome sequences and can be either genbank, fasta or fastq. The default is genbank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m84q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evh16","text":"For example, if you have FASTQ format reads that have file extension fatstq instead of ab1, you could run:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ef07g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4r5ig","text":"Or if you do not have an annotated reference genome, and want to instead use a sequence-only FASTA file:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6f2jm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8m57e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Run tnfind on fastq files","description":"","guid":"16B24324349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb --input-ext fastq","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with FASTA reference genome","description":"","guid":"572B021F349B11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.fasta --genome-type fasta","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6nqcg","text":"Quality control report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlns5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e67kl","text":"Optionally, tnfind can generate a fastqc quality control report for your sequencing reads, that contains information that will be useful if you intend to later trim your reads based on quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1m0ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gogg","text":"Passing the option -qc when running tnfind will generate the quality control report. The report will be saved in the output_dir in the file records_fastqc.html, you can open this file with your favourite web browser.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecjrk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3tnou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78vkk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1ftd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running fastqc as part of tnfind","description":"","guid":"AF101C31349311F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -qc","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"calo","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command fastqc on your computer system. If you have installed fastqc somewhere that is not on your PATH, you may also provide the path/to/fastqc to the -qc argument.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"68us3","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"63iv7","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vhd8","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with a custom location for fastqc","description":"","guid":"E0636618349311F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -qc /path/to/fastqc","os_name":"","os_version":""},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"command"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9l0nh","text":"Quality-based trimming","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ar1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ihvo","text":"To ensure that sequencing quality does not affect your results, you may wish to trim your input sequences where quality is low. tnfind can do this using the sickle tool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82hc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f20le","text":"Passing the option -trim when running tnfind will trim your reads before processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd7ui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"72vnk","text":"Optionally, the --trim-length and --trim-quality options can passed to tnfind to control the severity of the trimming.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbepu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8a108","text":"If --trim-length is not given explicitly, its default value is 20. If --trim-quality is not given explicitly, its default value is also 20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dubj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38cg4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e70p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a4cue","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qmtt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle to trim reads ","description":"","guid":"AA7960F7349411F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle and with custom trim length and quality","description":"","guid":"6951A560349511F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim --trim-length 30 --trim-quality 25","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7beij","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command sickle on your computer system. If you have installed sickle somewhere that is not on your PATH, you may also provide the path/to/sickle to the -trim argument.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ahil2","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b1tkf","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"gkvt","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle in a custom location","description":"","guid":"2479A5D6349611F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim /path/to/your/sickle","os_name":"","os_version":""},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"command"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5t0ts","text":"SAM output","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17suh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vrhu","text":"Part of tnfind's processing is a multiple sequence alignment between your sequencing reads and the reference genome(s). Optionally, this multiple sequence alignment may be saved in SAM format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe5sl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f68v3","text":"Passing the option -sam to tnfind will save a multiple sequence alignment in SAM format in the output_dir in the file samgenomes.sam.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk9po","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2idsq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with SAM output","description":"","guid":"F97F9F44349611F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -sam","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"avobh","text":"Obtaining help","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a95bt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aot5a","text":"There are many more optional arguments that control the behaviour of tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6j1fa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82urf","text":"They can be listed, alongside a short description of each, by running:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8h7i5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e5rap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Display the tnfind help","description":"","guid":"F086A60F349B11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind --help","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3fqlh","text":"Default outputs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"begpg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak68k","text":"results.xlsx is an excel spreadsheet containing the summary of the tnfind results.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dll","text":"tnfind also produces one GENBANK file per input read, which is annotated with the supposed transposon sequence and genome alignments for the read. The genome alignments are also annotated with corresponding genome features and loci, if those are available in the reference genome files.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2o18m","text":"results.xlsx","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79h3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhel2","text":"This is an excel spreadsheet which contains at least one row for every read in the input to tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2330v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56cqd","text":"If a particular read has multiple rows, then it was not possible to uniquely identify a position in the reference genome(s) for the transposon integration event. For example, because the integration has occurred within a genomic region which is repeated across the genome(s) (rRNAs for example, or genes with multiple copies, or genes that are shared among genomes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tlff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bstp5","text":"The columns of the excel describe various different statistics and information about the alignment. There are several groups.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34i0r","text":"Information about the sequencing read","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"148o5","text":"The first column is simply an indexing column and can be ignored.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtdj7","text":"The name column is the ID of the read obtained from the input file.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ad95","text":"The read length column is the length of the read (after trimming, if applicable).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6digf","text":"The multiple candidates column is true if the read has multiple rows and false otherwise. It can be used to filter uniquely identifiable integration events.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80vl6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d75d2","text":"Information about the transposon sequence found","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":47}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9im3s","text":"The transposon column contains the name of the supposed transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8at6f","text":"The transposon evalue column contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe7hf","text":"The transposon bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65tcd","text":"The transposon identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3f5dk","text":"The transposon length column indicates the length of the aligned part of the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j1t1","text":"The transposon start column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence begins.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfssg","text":"The transposon end column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence ends.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vr1e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nmur","text":"These columns are empty if no transposon sequence is found in the read.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33s2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cl28","text":"Information about the position in the genome","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6krss","text":"The genome offset column indicates the distance in base pairs between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j7dr","text":"The gap sequence is the read sequence (if any), between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41e9d","text":"The insertion locus is the name of the locus (if any) in the genome where the integration event is supposed to have occurred. This name comes from the annotated reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21bg2","text":"The insertion gene is the name of the gene into which the transposon sequence was integrated. This name comes from the annotated reference genome. If there is no such annotation this column shows \"None\"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l4ed","text":"The sequence type is the annotated type of the locus into which the integration has occurred. Again, this is taken from annotations on the reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26mub","text":"The insertion strand is the strand orientation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fit33","text":"The insertion product is the product annotation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8glg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a29f","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome, or if genome annotations are missing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsu8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ic5i","text":"Information about the genome alignment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rjd5","text":"The genome column contains the ID of the reference genome to which the read has been aligned.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dtv9","text":"The genome alignment evalue columns contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c29f","text":"The genome alignment bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ksj9","text":"The genome alignment identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbvk5","text":"The genome alignment length column contains the length in base pairs of the part of the read that was aligned to the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdd7v","text":"The genome alignment mismatch column contains the number of mismatches, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9fhr","text":"The genome alignment gaps column contains the number of gaps, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94srd","text":"The genome start column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9b6p","text":"The genome end column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63am1","text":"The genome strand column indicates the strand orientation on the genome of the alignment between the read and genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rk7u","text":"The genome loci column is a list of all the genomic loci contained within the genome alignment (as opposed to the single locus at the integration position reported in the insertion locus column).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":170,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o7qh","text":"The genome prefix column displays the sequence corresponding to the first 9 base pairs of genomic DNA contained in the read (the start of the read sequence that aligns with the genome). The size of the sequence displayed can be changed with the --genome-prefix option.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aud0p","text":"The genome alignment column shows the quality of the alignment of the genome prefix sequence with the genome. Exact matches are indicated with \"|\". Mismatches are indicated with \".\". Gaps are show as \"-\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16},{"style":"bold","offset":70,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eefr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f728h","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8pipg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c53nm","text":"Annotated reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq2q6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"132rh","text":"tnfind produces an annotated GENBANK file (file names ending in .processed.gb) for each input read that can be used to visually inspect the positions and alignments found to the both the transposon sequences and the genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62v1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45sgl","text":"These files can be opened using your favourite sequence viewer to see the arrangement of transposon and genomic sequences that tnfind thinks is most probable for each read. Genomic sequences are also annotated with features from their respective reference genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as1pv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64k8v","text":"An example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37g69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pddp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rkp9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d35i7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"332674E9404F11F090B80A58A9FEAC02","height":191,"id":584665,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8s9go\",\"text\":\"An example of the GENBANK output from tnfind. In this case, the read 22CCRRAA000_C05 is annotated with a transposon sequence alignment, plus the IR (Inverted repeat) feature. There is a small gap between the end of the transposon sequence and the genomic sequence, which comes from the genome AE015451.2 and contains the gene hmgA. In this case, the read aligned with the plus strand of AE015451.2, but the hmgA gene is coded for on the minus strand.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"labelled_gb_output.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tq95cpi5f.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t483cpi5f.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/traxcpi5f.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t482cpi5f.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"82d0h","text":"Download the example sequencing read files, transposon sequences file and reference genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"el70r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7lm8m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lp9e","text":"You can download the example data from https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk and unzip into a directory called data, or use the command:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":39,"length":38}],"data":{}},{"key":"7as6h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3cvd5","text":"To create a directory called data, under the tnfind-example directory, containing the example data files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88d0o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"affiliation":null,"can_edit":true,"guid":"2833B21B34AF11F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","link":"https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk","name":"tnfind example data"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3E2A721D34AD11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk"}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Download the example data and unzip","description":"","guid":"6AA2A47A34AD11F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"curl https://saco.csic.es/s/jtwG6EGPCjyJcRk/download -o data.zip \u0026\u0026 unzip data.zip \u0026\u0026 rm data.zip","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b482g","text":"Open the docker terminal ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8isfh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j5h4","text":"The lewisgrozinger/tnatlas docker image contains all the software you need in order to run tnfind. {"blocks":[{"key":"5732l","text":"Basic usage of tnfind","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4loer","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3be48","text":"tnfind finds possible transposon integration events in a set of sequencing reads and positions them in reference genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avp6r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2gqua","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"20vvd","text":"Other input formats, types and file extensions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86d4r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq0nr","text":"The following options in combination in order to process input files with different formats, types and file extensions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79bdc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h34n","text":"--input-type: is the format of the read files and should be either fasta or fastq. This can be anything. The default is ab1 if the --input-type is fastq or fasta if the --input-type is fasta.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6rfd","text":"--sequencing-type: the type of sequencing used to obtain the reads. {"blocks":[{"key":"6nqcg","text":"Quality control report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlns5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e67kl","text":"Optionally, tnfind can generate a fastqc quality control report for your sequencing reads, that contains information that will be useful if you intend to later trim your reads based on quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1m0ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gogg","text":"Passing the option -qc when running tnfind will generate the quality control report. {"blocks":[{"key":"9l0nh","text":"Quality-based trimming","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ar1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ihvo","text":"To ensure that sequencing quality does not affect your results, you may wish to trim your input sequences where quality is low. tnfind can do this using the sickle tool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82hc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f20le","text":"Passing the option -trim when running tnfind will trim your reads before processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd7ui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"72vnk","text":"Optionally, the --trim-length and --trim-quality options can passed to tnfind to control the severity of the trimming.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbepu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8a108","text":"If --trim-length is not given explicitly, its default value is 20. If --trim-quality is not given explicitly, its default value is also 20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dubj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38cg4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e70p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a4cue","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qmtt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"AA7960F7349411F084CB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Running tnfind with sickle and with custom trim length and quality","description":"","guid":"6951A560349511F0AD4F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"tnfind ./data ./data/results -transposon ./data/transposons.gb -genome ./data/genomes.gb -trim --trim-length 30 --trim-quality 25","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7beij","text":"By default, tnfind looks for a command sickle on your computer system. {"blocks":[{"key":"3fqlh","text":"Default outputs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"begpg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak68k","text":"results.xlsx is an excel spreadsheet containing the summary of the tnfind results.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dll","text":"tnfind also produces one GENBANK file per input read, which is annotated with the supposed transposon sequence and genome alignments for the read. {"blocks":[{"key":"2o18m","text":"results.xlsx","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79h3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhel2","text":"This is an excel spreadsheet which contains at least one row for every read in the input to tnfind. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2330v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56cqd","text":"If a particular read has multiple rows, then it was not possible to uniquely identify a position in the reference genome(s) for the transposon integration event. For example, because the integration has occurred within a genomic region which is repeated across the genome(s) (rRNAs for example, or genes with multiple copies, or genes that are shared among genomes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tlff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bstp5","text":"The columns of the excel describe various different statistics and information about the alignment. There are several groups.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34i0r","text":"Information about the sequencing read","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"148o5","text":"The first column is simply an indexing column and can be ignored.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtdj7","text":"The name column is the ID of the read obtained from the input file.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ad95","text":"The read length column is the length of the read (after trimming, if applicable).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6digf","text":"The multiple candidates column is true if the read has multiple rows and false otherwise. It can be used to filter uniquely identifiable integration events.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80vl6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d75d2","text":"Information about the transposon sequence found","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":47}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9im3s","text":"The transposon column contains the name of the supposed transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8at6f","text":"The transposon evalue column contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe7hf","text":"The transposon bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65tcd","text":"The transposon identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the transposon sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3f5dk","text":"The transposon length column indicates the length of the aligned part of the transposon sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j1t1","text":"The transposon start column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence begins.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfssg","text":"The transposon end column indicates the base pair position in the read where the alignment to the transposon sequence ends.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vr1e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nmur","text":"These columns are empty if no transposon sequence is found in the read.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33s2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cl28","text":"Information about the position in the genome","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6krss","text":"The genome offset column indicates the distance in base pairs between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j7dr","text":"The gap sequence is the read sequence (if any), between the end of the transposon alignment and the beginning of the genome alignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41e9d","text":"The insertion locus is the name of the locus (if any) in the genome where the integration event is supposed to have occurred. This name comes from the annotated reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21bg2","text":"The insertion gene is the name of the gene into which the transposon sequence was integrated. This name comes from the annotated reference genome. If there is no such annotation this column shows \"None\"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l4ed","text":"The sequence type is the annotated type of the locus into which the integration has occurred. Again, this is taken from annotations on the reference genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26mub","text":"The insertion strand is the strand orientation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fit33","text":"The insertion product is the product annotation of the locus into which the integration has occurred.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8glg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a29f","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome, or if genome annotations are missing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsu8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ic5i","text":"Information about the genome alignment","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rjd5","text":"The genome column contains the ID of the reference genome to which the read has been aligned.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dtv9","text":"The genome alignment evalue columns contains the evalue, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c29f","text":"The genome alignment bit score column contains the bit score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ksj9","text":"The genome alignment identity column contains the identity score, reported by blastn, of the alignment of the read to the genome sequence. 1 is 100% identity.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbvk5","text":"The genome alignment length column contains the length in base pairs of the part of the read that was aligned to the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdd7v","text":"The genome alignment mismatch column contains the number of mismatches, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9fhr","text":"The genome alignment gaps column contains the number of gaps, as reported by blastn, in the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94srd","text":"The genome start column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9b6p","text":"The genome end column indicates the base pair position in the reference genome of the start of the alignment between the read and the genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63am1","text":"The genome strand column indicates the strand orientation on the genome of the alignment between the read and genome.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rk7u","text":"The genome loci column is a list of all the genomic loci contained within the genome alignment (as opposed to the single locus at the integration position reported in the insertion locus column).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":170,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o7qh","text":"The genome prefix column displays the sequence corresponding to the first 9 base pairs of genomic DNA contained in the read (the start of the read sequence that aligns with the genome). The size of the sequence displayed can be changed with the --genome-prefix option.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aud0p","text":"The genome alignment column shows the quality of the alignment of the genome prefix sequence with the genome. Exact matches are indicated with \"|\". Mismatches are indicated with \".\". Gaps are show as \"-\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":16},{"style":"bold","offset":70,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eefr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f728h","text":"These columns are empty if there is no alignment to the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8pipg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c53nm","text":"Annotated reads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq2q6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"132rh","text":"tnfind produces an annotated GENBANK file (file names ending in .processed.gb) for each input read that can be used to visually inspect the positions and alignments found to the both the transposon sequences and the genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62v1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45sgl","text":"These files can be opened using your favourite sequence viewer to see the arrangement of transposon and genomic sequences that tnfind thinks is most probable for each read. Genomic sequences are also annotated with features from their respective reference genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as1pv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64k8v","text":"An example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37g69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pddp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rkp9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d35i7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"339FE3F4404F11F090B80A58A9FEAC02","height":191,"id":584667,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8s9go\",\"text\":\"An example of the GENBANK output from tnfind. In this case, the read 22CCRRAA000_C05 is annotated with a transposon sequence alignment, plus the IR (Inverted repeat) feature. There is a small gap between the end of the transposon sequence and the genomic sequence, which comes from the genome AE015451.2 and contains the gene hmgA. In this case, the read aligned with the plus strand of AE015451.2, but the hmgA gene is coded for on the minus strand.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"labelled_gb_output.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/tq95cpi5f.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t485cpi5f.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/traxcpi5f.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t484cpi5f.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b59eu","text":"It is sometimes useful to add additional data to the results.xlsx spreadsheet. The tnmeta tool can be used to attach metadata to each read, based on the plate and well from which the read was sampled.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lsae","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mas6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6523r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eat4","text":"The tnmeta tool requires 3 arguments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ktp4","text":"well_plate_regex is a regular expression that will be used to extract the plate and well number from the read IDs.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98lbf","text":"result_file is the file which is to be annotated with the metadata.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ul31","text":"metadata are the files which contain the maps of metadata.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hksh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au1ci","text":"By default, result_file is overwritten by tnmeta. If you don't want to overwrite result_file you can pass the option -o \u003cname/of/new/file\u003e to save the annotated results to a separate file.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":12,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":117,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n0n4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fp2l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fj8gk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"431no","text":"tnmeta is a command line tool that should be run through a terminal or terminal emulator such as xterm, gnome terminal, Windows powershell or iterm.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":20,"style":"bold"},{"length":11,"offset":148,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3oib","text":"If you already have result_file open in your spreadsheet software, you may encounter a permission denied error when trying to run tnmeta. Close the result_file spreadsheet first and try again.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4ikq5","text":"Well and plate regular expression","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eq8gg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cc25o","text":"The well_plate_regex argument is used to match read IDs to a specific plate, and to extract the well position from the read IDs. The regular expression should contain the keywords PLATE and WELL, which indicate the positions of the plate identifier and well position in the read ID. All other parts of the regular expression are interpreted using the Python re regular expression syntax.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":358,"length":29}],"data":{}},{"key":"7c649","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8nqc","text":"For example, if we have read IDs of the form \"22CCRAA000_A01_premix\", where \"22CCRAA000\" is the plate identifier and \"A01\" is the well position, we could use the regular expression:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ug5n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c52nj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fcj1d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fhvg","text":"Which means that tnmeta should expect the plate identifier to come first, then an underscore, then the well position, followed by another underscore.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qi33","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9q29r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dcsfk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8D3BE8A8B59F4049B1ED1E88B903E3A2","url":"https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax"}},"1":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eckte","text":"PLATE_WELL_","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":16,"offset":104,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bspqg","text":"To avoid problems due to shell expansion of regular expression wildcards, it is a good idea to pass the well_plate_regex argument inside quotes, for example, 'PLATE_WELL_'","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4asab","text":"Naming the metadata file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6acd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"941r8","text":"The name of the metadata file will be used to determine to which plate the metadata corresponds, and the name of the new column that should contain the metadata in the results table.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqj69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7fl8q","text":"The name of the file must begin with an alphanumeric plate identifier, followed by an underscore, followed by an alphanumeric column name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1o8oo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5s0ck","text":"A file \"PLATE_COLUMN.xlsx\" will look for reads from the plate called PLATE, and add metadata to reads in a new column called COLUMN.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cbsb4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bu7uq","text":"You should rename your metadata files accordingly.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b59eu","text":"It is sometimes useful to add additional data to the results.xlsx spreadsheet. The tnmeta tool can be used to attach metadata to each read, based on the plate and well from which the read was sampled.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lsae","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mas6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6523r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eat4","text":"The tnmeta tool requires 3 arguments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ktp4","text":"well_plate_regex is a regular expression that will be used to extract the plate and well number from the read IDs.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98lbf","text":"result_file is the file which is to be annotated with the metadata.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ul31","text":"metadata are the files which contain the maps of metadata.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hksh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au1ci","text":"By default, result_file is overwritten by tnmeta. Close the result_file spreadsheet first and try again.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"aibt2","text":"This is a workflow for the genotypic characterization of transposon library variants. It has been developed using an open-source Opentrons OT-2 robot, BLASTN for genomic annotations and modular sub-protocols (e.g., PCR sample preparation, OT-2 volume transfer, OT-2 counter selection, etc) that can be used for other tasks, thus providing a general-purpose pipeline. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1l9n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60tpn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fv5f2","text":"All steps follow a 96-well plate format for high-throughput analysis. The protocol is described for the characterization of transposon library variants generated with SEVA-Sib pBAMD1-x and pBLAM1-x plasmid sets that follow Standard European Vector Architecture (SEVA, https://seva-plasmids.com) and can be amplified with the standard PS1-PS6 primers. However, it can be adapted for other transposon systems.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":268,"length":25}],"data":{}},{"key":"7v6k5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4mncr","text":"Changes from previous version:  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98c5k","text":"- This version references updated OT-2 automation protocols which now follow the standardized LAP format (https://www.laprepo.com). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":106,"length":23}],"data":{}},{"key":"9gq9b","text":"- Genotyping is performed with a new ad hoc python package to annotate genomic reads and identify the transposon insertion sites.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48dlq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40ojr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cj5cq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"elg02","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8B709A7A556811EDB33C0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://seva-plasmids.com"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"1A91F3D3B08D11EE93C30A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.laprepo.com"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"2lpap","text":"This workflow comprises the following sections: 1) Colony picking in selective media 2) Counter-selection and glycerol stocks pre-cultures 3) Colony selection in OT-2 liquid handler robot 4) Master 96-well plate for PCR steps 5) Control PCRs (spurious plasmid integration control and cargo insertion control) 5) Arbitrary PCRs 6) Sequencing and annotation. There is an additional section with an example on how to run the script.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"509a2","text":"We recommend the use of an OT-2 protocol specially if more than 2 libraries are to be analyzed. However, we recommend to do counter-selection in the OT-2 liquid handling robot even for one plate to avoid human errors.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7phb","text":"Note that other pipettes can be used to run the workflow in the OT-2 but these were deemed the most appropriate for the overall workflow to minimize pipette changes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
